quote: You know, Morn -- there's nothing quite as invigorating as breakfast in a bar. Where else can you get raw slug livers first thing in the morning?
What's this?
What do you mean, "what's this?" It's puree of beetle.
I didn't order it.
Of course you "didn't order it" -- you don't need to order it. You have it after work every morning.
Well, I'm not having it this morning. I'd like two eggs, over easy with three strips of bacon and a side of corned beef hash.
What kind of breakfast is that?
It's Chief O'Brien's breakfast of choice.
That's the problem with working alongside Hew-mons, you pick up their disgusting habits. Bacon. Corned beef hash... What's next? Orange juice and coffee?
That might be nice.
I don't understand it. You gave up a perfectly good job with me to work on the station's waste extraction system.
A good waste extraction system is important. Imagine where we'd be without one.
Of course it's important -- but my point is, you're not getting the choice assignments. O'Brien's got you on the night shift doing all the work no one else wants to do.
(doesn't see the problem) I like my work.
You like standing all night long, knee-deep in waste, fixing some broken flow regulator? When you could be here --
-- staring at half-naked dabo girls?

I have a good job. I'm proud of the work I do. And I know that one day, Chief O'Brien will recognize my efforts and reward me with a position of respect and responsibility. And why? Because that's just the way things are... in Engineering.
I'm sorry I brought it up.
They looked fine last night.
They don't look so fine now.
I can't understand it... I've been following Keiko's instructions to the letter...
They were dry as a bone when I came by for you yesterday. I gave them water, but I guess it wasn't enough.
You watered them?
These are Idran hybrids. Too much water rots their roots.
Oh.
Mommy's going to be mad.
I can't believe it. Keiko's been gone for five days and we've killed her plants.
She'll understand, won't she? After all, they're just plants.
They're not "just plants" - they're her bonsai trees.
She's nurtured them and cared for them, carefully sculpted their growth for... months... years.
You're in trouble.
Molly, honey, listen... why don't we both go to the airlock and welcome Mommy back together. Then after we've hugged and kissed her, you can explain what happened.
Not me.
Don't look at me.
You killed her plants.
We killed them.
But I think you're overreacting to the situation. Keiko will forgive you. After all, today's your birthday, right?
So far, it's one I'd like to forget.
And Keiko's been away on Bajor -- she's missed you. Bring her a gift -- what's her favorite chocolate?
Tellurian mint truffles. But I still think you should be there with me.

You don't need me. You know how to handle your own wife -- I've seen you do it a thousand times. Just say you're sorry and take full responsibility. You'll be fine. Besides, I'll be in surgery -- operating.
On who?
I'll find somebody.
It was Julian. He overwatered them. He was trying to be helpful -- but you know how he is, he doesn't always know what he's doing.
I'm sorry, sweetheart. We'll get new ones.
Forget it, Miles. They're just plants.
Exactly.
It's not as if something happened to Molly or the baby.
Right. Everyone's just fine. No problems at all.
Good. What about Kira - is she back?
No, she's still with Shaakar traveling around Dahkur Province. I thought you were going to visit them.
I didn't have a chance.
Fine. And now it's time for me to tell you something.
I'm not Keiko.
Then who are you?
Listen carefully, Miles. I've taken possession of your wife's body and I will hold it hostage until you've done everything I tell you to do -- accurately, and without question.
Everything?
If you don't do precisely what I ask, I'll kill your wife.
Maybe there's been an outbreak of Rudellian brain fever on Bajor. Let's go down and see Julian, so he can...
I see you're going to need a demonstration of my sincerity.
No!
No, Miles. You're not telling anyone. If you do, I'll stop her heart... forever.
If you're really in control of my wife's body, let me speak to her.
She can "hear" whatever you want to say.
That's not good enough. I want to talk to her -- I want her to talk to me.
You're in no position to make any demands, Miles.
Strange, these corporeal bodies of yours. So fragile. Burst a tiny blood vessel in the brain and every memory, every passionate emotion... Gone forever.
You shouldn't let me eat all of these by myself.
I'm not hungry.
Why don't you just tell me what ou want me to do so we can get this over with.
Very well...
But I want to make one thing clear -- I won't do anything that'll jeopardize this station or the people on it.
Don't worry, Miles. All I want you to do is reconfigure some of the communication and sensor relays on the station.
What for?
I can't tell you that.
You're going to have to be patient. The communication and sensor relays are distributed throughout the entire station.
You know your wife well, Miles. But she knows you even better.

You're playing for time so you can get to your friends. Dax, Julian, Captain Sisko -- I know they'll all want to help you. The captain may even allow you to do what I'm asking -- at least until someone can figure a way to "trap me" in some kind of stasis field or some other clever device you're already dreaming up.

And you know what? It might work. You might be able to stop me. (then cold and hard as steel) But I promise you one thing -- if you do, Keiko will die. All I need is a split second to cause a massive brain hemorrhage... ... and she's gone.
I realize this is a difficult adjustment for you to make, but we don't have a lot of time.
What do you want me to do?
How long is this going to take?
Two hours to make the modifications and five or six hours to cover my tracks. If I don't -- my crew will catch on to what I'm doing before you can say isolinear injunction.
I'm glad to see some of your good humor returning.
This doesn't need to be an unpleasant experience.
In order to keep the polarity shift invisible to security checks, I'll have to tap into the optronic integrator on Level Five.
You're the engineer.
What is it, Miles? What do you want to ask me? You always tighten your brow just a tiny bit when you're about to ask a question -- it's something only a wife would notice.
Why Keiko? Why take control of her -- and not me? I'm the one who knows how to do the work. It'd be more efficient --
Come in.
Hope I'm not interrupting...
You are. We're busy.
Miles! Don't be rude.
Did you tell her?
Bajoran spiny basil... how thoughtful!
It's the least I can do after...
It's all right, Julian. I forgive you. Now, you are going to make it to the party tonight, aren't you?
I'll be here. I guess it's not a surprise anymore.
I can't believe I did that. I arranged a birthday dinner for you tonight. But I wanted it to be a surprise.
It's okay. I don't like surprises.
I better go. I left a patient on the operating table. I'll see you later.
Thanks, Julian. This was sweet.
A party? Tonight?
It is your birthday.
We can't have all those people here. We'll have to cancel it.
And raise suspicions? It's better if the dinner goes on as planned. Besides, your wife went through a lot of trouble to arrange it.
You'd better get to work -- you don't want to be late for your shift briefing and I've got a lot of cooking to do.
Diagnostic and Repair Technician, Junior Grade Rom reporting.
Right. You're Duarte's replacement. Have a seat.
I'm on the swing shift?
For a day or two.
What's the matter with Duarte?
Sick as a vole.
Is this where Duarte sits?
(looking at their coffee mugs) So, what are you drinking?
Raktajino.
Great. Is that what we drink on the swing shift?
You can drink anything you want.
I'll have a raktajino.
It's not like this on the night shift.
We don't drink raktajino... We don't really drink anything.
Fascinating.
(glancing over at the door) Wonder what's keeping the chief -- he's never late for a briefing.
That's married life for you. Just as I'm walking out the door -- my wife always comes up with something I forgot to do.
Change of plans today, people.
I need to recalibrate the optronic integrator on Level Five.
What is it, Rom?
I volunteer. I like phase- shifting reconfigurations.
Thank you, but I'll do that myself. I want the rest of you to concentrate on the new inertial coupling ports. I want all sixty- four ports completed today.

Whatley -- you and Tekoa cover the docking ring. Abdon and Nori, the cargo bays. Rom -- the upper pylons. Any questions? Good. One more thing -- since I'm working alone today, I'm going to be very busy. Try not to interrupt me with anything unimportant. Is that clear?
Computer, locate Keiko O'Brien.
Keiko O'Brien is in her quarters.
Computer, initiate a full identity scan on Keiko O'Brien and note inconsistencies with any existing medical records.
Scan complete. No inconsistencies found. Identity confirmed.
How long would it take for a level three stasis field to render Keiko O'Brien unconscious?
All cognitive reflexes would cease in two-point-one seconds.
Too long. Calculate the time if anesthetine gas were used.
One-point-four seconds.
What about a phaser set to stun?
Zero-point-nine seconds.
Damn it.
God help me...
There you are, Chief. I was beginning to think you were going to miss your own party.
Sorry I'm late. Had to tie up a few loose ends. Where's Keiko?
In the bedroom, helping Molly put on different shoes -- a little fashion crisis. But as usual, your wife has handled everything. You're a lucky man, Miles.
She's really outdone herself this time. Take it from an old cook -- Q'parol is a very time-consuming dish to make.
Make a wish.
Happy birthday, sweetheart.
Single malt Irish whiskey. Neat. Molly wanted to wear her new purple shoes for you. Doesn't she look pretty?
Very pretty.
All the food's out on the table, dear, so just relax with our friends. (taking the tray of drinks) I'll pass these around.
I need to talk to you.
Not right now, Miles... we have guests.
Sorry I'm late.
Dax! I was afraid you weren't going to make it.
I heard you were serving Q'parol. How could I stay away?
What's the matter, Chief? You seem preoccupied. Is everything all right?
It's nothing. I just forgot to tell Keiko something... would you excuse me for a moment?
Of course.
Did you meet any Pah-wraiths?
Pah-wraiths?
In the Fire Caves. Odo was telling me the caves were haunted by some sort of weird supernatural beings.
Don't tell me you believe in wraiths?
I may have mentioned the Bajoran legends about creatures living in the caves. But I never said I believed them.
Well, the only thing I saw in the caves were some very beautiful and botanically fascinating fungi.
Well, maybe next time you go to the Fire Caves, I could come along. I've always wanted to meet a Pah- wraith.
Maybe you will. You never know...
I've done what you wanted.
That's terrific, Miles. You can tell me all about it... later.
Can I have cake now?
In a bit, sweetie.
Miles -- are you bleeding?
No, I'm all right. It's nothing --
Let me look at that.
I said it's nothing.
I'm sorry. Sorry, everybody.
Excuse me...
Get a hold of yourself.
I've done what you wanted. Now give me my wife back.
You've done well, Miles.
But recalibrating the optronic integrator was only a test. I had to be sure I could trust you. Tomorrow, the real work begins.
Now it's time we got back to our guests. We don't want to raise any suspicions, do we?
Is Molly asleep?
Yes.
(showing him the empty casserole) The Q'parol was a big success.
No more games. No more tests. Just tell me what you want done.
We'll talk about it in the morning. It's late and you're working a double shift tomorrow.
I want to talk about it now.
Miles -- I make the rules. Now relax. Everything's going to be fine as long as you do what I ask.
Let's go to bed.
I'm sleeping on the couch.
Don't be childish. What if Molly has one of her nightmares and comes running in? You'll sleep next to me, just like you always do.
I'll be there in a minute.
Don't stay up too late. You've got a busy day tomorrow.
Computer. I want to see a record of all Bajoran legends concerning the Pah-wraiths.
There are six thousand, four hundred, twenty-seven entries in the data banks that reference that subject. Please specify.
Miles...
Sleep well, Miles.
scene: 17   INT. O'BRIEN'S BEDROOM - OVERHEAD ON O'BRIEN

quote: Another weakness of you corporeal lifeforms: your need for physical intimacy.
It's especially irritating in your young.
I've got to get Molly ready for school.
I'll do it. You have a big day ahead of you.
Molly's going to sleep at the Davis's tonight, and she's staying there until this is over.
Do you really think that's wise? A little girl needs her mother. Molly would be lost without hers.
You keep away from her.
Miles... I would never do anything to hurt your daughter... Unless you force me to.
These are your instructions. Follow them precisely.
Recalibrating and sequencing the impulse response filters in the subspace communication emitters... what's all that for?
We've gone over this, Miles. It's not your concern.
Then how do I know this won't jeopardize the station?
Because I've told you so. Now stop asking me so many questions. All it's doing is making me angry. And you know who pays the price for that, don't you?
I almost forgot -- here's your birthday present.
Go ahead, open it. It's from your wife.
There's an inscription on the back.
Your wife cares about you very much.
Computer, locate Captain Sisko.
Captain Sisko is in Security.
Miles!
I love you.
No!
Doctor Bashir to the Promenade!
You didn't see anyone near her before she fell?
Nobody. But I was passing under the walkway and my back was to her.
(curious, not accusatory) What were you doing on the Promenade?
What?
Weren't you supposed to be working on some optronic circuitry on Level Five?
I was going to the Replimat... for lunch.
Keiko's going to be all right. She's lucky she landed the way she did. It distributed the impact. A fall from that height could easily have killed her, or left her paralyzed.
Is she conscious?
Yes, but she's still in shock. She has a broken femur and a hairline fracture of the right parietal bone.
Can I see her?
Maybe in a couple of hours. She needs rest.
Julian -- I have to see her now.
Doctor.
All right -- but only for a few minutes. Don't excite her.
Keiko?
You were going to tell them about me.
How did you know?
I know everything your wife knows -- and she knows you. I told you we have to trust one another. You violated that trust, and look where it's led us.
I want my wife back, do you hear me? I want her back.
Then stop trying to fool me. How much more damage do you think this body can take?
Now, no more tricks. Agreed?
Say it.
Agreed.
Good. You know what you need to do. You should get back to work.
I'll have everything completed in thirty-six hours.
You have thirteen -- and not a minute more.
I can't do it that fast.
You're a very resourceful man You'll find a way... For Keiko's sake.
You bloody --
She needs to rest.
Tell Molly I'll be home soon. Tell her Mommy is fine. Don't scare her.
Miles... give me a kiss.
I'm counting on you.
She'll be back on her feet soon. I promise.
Computer. Begin a thirteen hour countdown. Now.
Clock activated.
Chief.
I heard about Mrs. O'Brien's accident. How is she?
Julian says she'll be home soon.
That's good. Is there anything I can do to help?
I wish there was, Worf. I really do. I've got to go -- I'm falling behind schedule.
Computer, time?
Eight hours, twenty-two minutes and three seconds remain.
Chief.
Sorry -- I didn't mean to startle you.
What are you doing here?
Reporting for my next assignment. I've completed calibration tests on the inertial coupling ports on all three upper pylons.
Already?
How'd you finish so quickly?

I just did the work. I didn't allow myself to get caught up in any of the distracting discussions the other workers engage in. Ferengi can be very focused. Especially when no one bothers to talk to them.
I see.
Not that I mind. I'm used to being ignored.
Is something wrong, Chief? I can work slower if you want me to...
Rom... I need your help, and I need you to keep your mouth shut. Can I count on you?
Is that a trick question?
Rom -- this is serious.
You can depend on me, Chief.
We're going to make some modifications to several of the station's systems. You're not to breathe one word about this to anyone. That includes Dax, Odo, Captain Sisko, Worf...
They don't know?
Of course they know. Some of them, anyway. But they have to pretend they don't. This is a top secret Starfleet operation.
Culpable deniability. I understand. Don't worry about me, Chief. My lips are sealed. Nobody will get anything out of me. Not even my name.
Rom, everybody on the station knows your name.
Right. But I won't confirm it. Where do we start?
I hope you feel rested, because you won't be getting any sleep tonight.
First, I want you to complete this com relay bypass...
Computer, time remaining?
Six hours, forty-one minutes, twenty-six seconds.
Commander, what are you doing up at this hour?
I want you to look at something.
I couldn't sleep so I got up and decided to scan the wormhole for radiometric anomalies.
At three in the morning?
I find anomalies very relaxing. I was using the wideband filter protocols and when I ran the primary calibration check I found this --
They're slightly off spec.
Yes. I thought it might be a fused matrix inverter, until I ran a level three diagnostic. Have a look.
We'd better wake the captain. We have a saboteur on the station.
All right, what have you got?
Computer, display diagnostic.
Chief...
We've identified nine hundred and forty-three tiny fluctuations in the primary communication relays and several power distribution junctions.
"Fluctuations" that can't be attributed to anything except external intervention.
Someone's gained access to our systems and is altering them. For what purpose?
We're working on that. At this point, it's hard to even call it sabotage -- there's been no real damage...
... the systems are just slightly off spec. So far, none of these alterations appear to pose a threat to the station.
So far. But this might be just the tip of a very large and dangerous iceberg.
Is there any way to trace how this was done, and by whom?
It has to be someone familiar with the station's systems.
Maybe someone who worked on the station under the Cardassians...
I'm running extensive security checks on all recent visitors, but so far, I haven't found anything.
It could be someone who's been on the station a long time... someone with a lot of access... maybe even someone on the maintenance crew.
Chief?
Yes.
Yes, what? You think it's someone on your staff?
Chief O'Brien, I have a call from your daughter.
Go ahead, Chief.
Molly, honey, what is it?
Hi, Daddy. Mommy told me I could call you.
I hope we're not interrupting anything important.
It's all right, Molly. I'm glad you called. What are you doing home?
She missed her mommy. Isn't that sweet?
When are you going to come --
Oww! Mommy, that hurt.
I'm sorry.
Are you all right, sweetie?
She's fine, Miles. She wants to know when you'll be finished. I told her you had to work for another two hours and twenty-two minutes and thirteen seconds.
How long is that, Daddy?
I'll be home soon, sweetie. Very soon.
Good. We both miss you.
Everything all right?
Fine. Sorry about the interruption.
You were saying you thought you knew who the saboteur might be...
I think I have an idea...
Hello, Constable. Hello, Chief.
What are you doing, Rom?
I-I can't talk about it.
Oh, yes you can. And you will.
I'll take care of those.
Coming, Chief?
I'd better see what he's been up to here.
Has he said anything?
Not much. For the first forty minutes, it was like pulling teeth even getting him to admit his name.
You think he's working alone?
I don't know. Rom admits to nothing. And now he's asking for Chief O'Brien. He won't talk to anybody else.
Then get the chief down here. I want to know what's going on.
Security to Chief O'Brien.
Go ahead, Constable.
We need you in Security right away.
I'm still trying to figure out what Rom did to these systems.
That will have to wait. I have captain's orders to get you down here -- immediately.
On my way.
Computer, time remaining?
Thirty-six minutes and nine seconds.
Computer, locate maintenance technician Rom.
Maintenance technician Rom is in Security holding cell number four.
Initiate security override and scramble Surveillance Channels Four A, B, C and D. Authorization O'Brien seven-one-two.
Specified security channels scrambled.
Now begin recalibration of gravitic sensors at Access Panel Three Nine Seven as indicated. I'll return in ten minutes.
The chief is here, Rom. Now what do you have to say?
Alone. I'll only talk if we're alone.
What is it, Rom?
It's all right. I disconnected Odo's eavesdropping devices.
I haven't told anyone anything, just like you said.
You're a good man. Now why'd you call for me? I told you we were under very tight time constraints.
Captain Sisko is really angry. If I didn't know he was pretending...
Rom...
Don't worry, I can hold out until you say otherwise, but there is one thing I have to know...
Go ahead.
Why are we focusing a chroniton beam at the wormhole?
What?

The new frequency of the deflector grid is set to turn the station into a massive chroniton array aimed directly at the wormhole. So I just want to know -- why are we trying to kill the wormhole aliens?
What are you talking about? A chroniton beam is harmless.
To us -- but its temporal disruption would kill a wormhole alien instantly.
Of course, why didn't I think of that. She's had me so on edge I couldn't see the forest for the trees.
Who's "she?"
Look, I don't have time to explain. The question is why would anyone want to kill the wormhole aliens?
Everyone has enemies, even the Prophets.

That's right... they're not just wormhole aliens... they're Prophets. They're part of Bajoran mythology... (everything is beginning to fall into place) ... just like the Pah-wraiths that live in the Fire Caves. So the question is... what do these wraiths have to do with the wormhole aliens?
Koss'moran.
What?
It's a Bajoran legend. From the verb kosst, meaning "to be" and amoran -- "banished". Leeta's been telling me all about Bajoran legends. She can go on for hours. She says I'm a good listener...
I'm sure you are -- but now's the time to be a good talker. Go on.
Well... according to Leeta, the Pah-wraiths used to live in the wormhole. They were part of the Celestial Temple.
They were Prophets?
False Prophets... They were cast out of the Temple. Exiled to the caves, they were imprisoned in crystal fire cages and forbidden to ever return "lest they face the Wrath of the True Prophets."
So if a False Prophet tried to return to the Celestial Temple...
I don't think they'd be welcomed.
Unless she kills all the wormhole aliens first... Rom -- I'm going to have to leave you in a tough spot.
Captain Sisko... Odo... they don't know about any of this, do they?
No, Rom. They don't. And you have to help me keep it that way for a little while longer.
I have to stay here and play the idiot?
I'm afraid so. Whatever Odo asks you --
I'm Quark's brother. I know the role.
Computer, time remaining?
Twelve minutes, twenty-two seconds.
Sorry to disturb you, Chief. But a couple of things are still bothering me. Rom couldn't have done all this sabotage alone. There were too many changes for any one person to make.
(keeping focused on his task) Maybe so, but right now I've got a frequency problem in the cascade feeder...
I checked with the repair logs... I was hoping to match someone's movements to the locations where the alterations were made.
But I couldn't do that.
We had a matrix system failure yesterday and those records were lost. Sorry.
We've had a lot of system failures recently, haven't we, Chief?
I hadn't noticed. I've been busy repairing things.
Like the surveillance channels in the holding cells? You authorized a security override. What was wrong with them?
The fiber optic relays were out of sync. The isolinear chip junction was --
Enough, Chief.
You didn't cover your tracks very well. Why?
I didn't have time. I still don't.
Sorry, Odo. Chief O'Brien to Keiko O'Brien.
This is Keiko.
I'm finished, but we've got to move quickly. (looking at the fallen Odo) This place is going to be swarming with security -- meet me at Runabout Pad "C." Now.
How did you know I'd want a runabout?

Because I know what you're planning to do. But don't worry, I don't give a damn about the Celestial Temple, or your non- corporeal feuds. I just want my wife back. Now you still need me to pilot you to the wormhole so let's stop wasting time. Agreed?
I'll meet you there.
That's correct, Commander. I want to test some new magnetic constrictors on the runabout's impulse thrusters.
Very well, Chief. You're cleared for departure, but before you go, there's one thing I'd like to ask you.
What's that?
Did you enjoy your birthday?
It was full of surprises.
Hold position here.
Computer. Initiate modifications O'Brien seven-three-one and enable remote com-link.
Com-link enabled.
What the hell --
Target the center of the wormhole.
Target coordinates, set.
Have us face the Temple. The blast will only last a fraction of a second... They'll all be dead before they even see it.
You have no idea how many centuries I've waited for this...
Let's get on with it.
You have a lot to learn about patience, Miles.
Proceed.
Chief -- what's going on out there?
I'm ordering you to return to the station -- now!
Activate.
Keiko!
Miles?
You have some explaining to do, Chief.
It was more like having something coiled around inside my head. I could see and hear through it, but every time I tried to do anything, it was like... ... like being stuck in sand, then squeezed.
Could you sense any of its thoughts?
Just feelings, sometimes. Kind of a cold rage. I don't think it ever had any intention of leaving either one of us alive.
You don't have to talk about it if you don't want to.
It feels good to talk about it. Besides... (looks fondly at O'Brien) I'll never forget how hard you fought for me.
Hello, brother.
You look horrible. I'm telling you, Rom -- working the night shift is driving you to an early grave.
I wasn't working.
What do you mean you weren't working?
I'm not on the night shift anymore.
I knew it. O'Brien fired you.
No, Brother. In appreciation of my work the chief has promoted me to the day shift... he says I have a promising future in Engineering.
Then why do you look so tired?
I was out celebrating.
With who?
My crewmates.
I think they like me.
Do they?
Especially Litana, she's always finding excuses to talk to me.
Well, I'm glad things are going so well for you, Rom.
No, you're not. But thanks anyway, brother.
So I suppose you'll be wanting - the "Chief's Special" again?
Actually, no. I've discovered bacon doesn't agree with me.
What a surprise.
Instead, I'll have a short stack of pancakes, dripping with butter, side of sausage and pineapple.
Pineapple?
That's the breakfast of choice on the day shift.
Pineapple.
Good morning, Constable. What can I do for you today?
It's my back...
Let's have a look.
It happened this morning when I got out of bed...
Hmm...
I have Alvanian spine mites, don't I?
Actually --
I'm going to be in pain for the rest of my life.
Odo. You have a pinched nerve.
Really?
It comes from bad posture.
Bad posture? Me? Ridiculous. You've never seen anyone sit so straight.
Exactly. You're carrying yourself too rigidly.
This is how I've always carried myself.
You didn't always have a spinal column. You're not a changeling anymore. Now that you're humanoid, you need to learn to relax.
That's what you said last week.
And?
It helped. That and the prune juice.
There -- you see? I know what I'm talking about.
Back trouble?
It's none of your concern, Quark.
Bad posture?
Will you get out of here!
What you need is a stretching regimen. Worf's morning exercise class would be just the thing.
Forget that. I've got a holosuite program that'll take care of him. Three Orion slave girls strap you into a --
Quark.
Go ahead. Suffer.
What do you want?
A Yridian I've been dealing with sold me something that might interest you.
I don't think so.
You don't even know what it is.
I know I don't want it.
In that case, can you tell me how to get in touch with the Founders? I know they'll want it.
What are you talking about?
It's a changeling -- or it was, anyway. Since it's dead, I'll let you have it for five slips of latinum.
It's not dead.
In that case, make it ten.
It's sick.
Eight and we'll call it even.
Pleasure doing business with you.
Odo... if that is a changeling, we'd better get it into a security field.
That won't be necessary.
If it gets out of that container, it could be dangerous.
It's not going anywhere, Doctor. It doesn't know how... it's just a baby.
A baby changeling?
Centuries ago, my people sent a hundred of us out into the galaxy so we could learn about other races. When I was found, I looked very much like this.
You were this... small?
Like a humanoid child, it'll grow. Its mass will increase as its shape-shifting abilities develop.
From what I can tell, it was exposed to a massive dose of tetryon radiation. I'm going to have to purge the isotopes with an electrophoretic diffuser.
Get on it.
Are you sure it's no danger to us, Constable?
When I was first discovered, I didn't know what I was, or have any memory of where I came from. I didn't even know I had the ability to mimic other forms.
Why would the Founders send such helpless creatures out into space?
To find out if the species they encountered posed any threat. What better way to gauge another race than to see how it treats the weak and vulnerable?
I see your point.
Several months. Why?
There's a lot about your people we still don't know. The changeling could provide Starfleet with invaluable information about the Dominion.
That being the case, I'd like to be allowed to work with it -- teach it how to shape-shift.
I can't think of anyone better qualified. But you might want a little help. Maybe you should contact Doctor Mora.
Mora? Why?
He managed to find a way to communicate with you. He obviously knows what he's doing.
Maybe so. But I'd prefer to do this alone.
It's your call. But it's always nice to have someone around to help change the diapers.
I'll keep that in mind...
The purge was nearly a hundred percent effective -- the concentration of isotopes is almost negligible.
It certainly looks healthier...
I'd better go check on Kira. Did you hear? She's in labor.
Mm-mm...
I guess you've got your own baby to think about.
There's still a small degree of instability in its morphogenic matrix. I'm hoping it'll level out. I set the computer to monitor for biomimetic fluctuations just in case.
Thank you, Doctor.
Good luck.
How do you feel -- better?

I realize you can't understand a word I'm saying, but that doesn't matter. I know you're aware of me. You see, I was once like you. I spent months in a lab being poked and prodded by a scientist who didn't even realize I was a lifeform. I was just a specimen, a mystery that needed to be unraveled. He never talked to me. It didn't occur to him. I didn't know what I was, or what I was supposed to do. I was lost, alone.
But it's not going to be that way for you. I'm not going to make the same mistakes that were made with me.
Something's wrong... Kira told me this would only take about an hour.
For Bajoran women, giving birth is all about being relaxed...
(glancing at the gong in his hand) He's right, Miles... that's why it's important for us to keep the rhythm...
I don't think she's going to relax until Shakaar gets here.
I called almost six hours ago; it takes less than half that to make the trip from Bajor.
He's the First Minister of Bajor -- he's a busy man...
So am I... I've got three surgeries scheduled this afternoon. I'll try to pop in later.
Y'Pora... the baby... he's moving...
Relax... breathe... it won't be long now.
Sorry I'm late --
How are you?
I threw you off, didn't I?
It's all right, I'll get back on track. I'm glad you're here.
This is the Replimat. Humanoids come here to eat. They -- we, rather -- need to ingest nutrients.

This is my home. It's a space station. People of many different species live here together. Once you've learned to take humanoid shape, I'll show you everything. You can live here, too, if you want. It's a fascinating place.
Constable --
Why are you talking to your beverage?
It's not a beverage, it's a changeling.
Why did you bring it here?
I wanted it to see the station. This is a Klingon.
I came to talk to you about the Ferengi.
He means Quark. I suppose you'll have to meet him sooner or later.
I believe he has been tapping into the station's computer and downloading secured information.
That's illegal.
We need to set up a data reversion trace.
I'm chief of security, that's my job.
If we can apprehend him, it may be possible to revoke his licence and force him to close his establishment.
Quark runs a bar.
Odo.
What?
Thank you for your time.
As you can see, Klingons are a bit short-tempered.
There... doesn't that feel better? There's nothing like spreading yourself out after being cooped up in a jar.

You have no idea of the marvels that are in store for you. Do you know what you are? You're a changeling. A Shape-shifter. You can be anything. A Tarkalean hawk, soaring through the sky. Or a Filian python, burrowing deep beneath the ground. It's all yours for the taking.

I was never a very good Shape-shifter -- if you could see the face I'm stuck with, you'd know what I mean -- but I think I can be a good teacher. You'll be better than I ever was. And I promise, I'll never treat you the way I was treated. Never.
Odo.
Doctor Mora... what are you doing here?
I heard about the changeling. I came to help.
Is that it?
Remarkable...
It looks a bit larger than you were. There must be what, a quarter of a liter?
I suppose so.
You haven't measured?
What difference does it make how big it is?
It could make a great deal of difference. Its size could be an indication that it's already exercised its shape-shifting abilities.
I thought you were on Earth, working with Starfleet on new ways to detect changeling infiltrators.
Fortunately, I happened to be on Bajor visiting my parents when I got word of your find.
How are you, Odo? I've been worried.
Worried?
I heard your people had taken away your ability to shape-shift.
Thank you for your concern. But I'm fine.
I knew you were going to say that. You never want to give anything away. Even though it's all right there on your face.
Well, why don't we get started? We have a lot of work ahead of us.
Actually, doctor --
I told Starfleet that I won't be coming back for a few weeks.
That may have been premature.
It'll take at least that long to get the changeling to respond to --
Don't do that.
I see you still have trouble controlling your temper.
I just wanted to determine its mass.
Doctor Mora... I understand that you want to help, but I'm going to do this alone.
Alone? But, Odo... you don't know the first thing about teaching a changeling how to shape-shift.
I'll muddle through somehow. You did.
It's too warm in here. A changeling's morphogenic matrix is most malleable at seventeen degrees Celsius.
I used to be able to change my shape in almost any temperature.
But why not make it easy for the changeling.
It took me weeks to determine the optimal temperature, humidity, even the light level. Don't you think that's information you could use?
I suppose I could take a look at your reports.
You're free to, of course. But I was never one to keep extensive records. I always wanted to move on to the next test.
Believe me, I remember your "tests" very well.

Ah, that's what this is all about. You still resent the things I did to induce you to shape-shift. I know they weren't pleasant for you, but really, Odo -- I'd have hoped you'd have moved past that by now. I'm disappointed.
I have my own ideas about how to teach the changeling.
Really? I take it they're less... invasive?
Exactly.
Hmm.
You don't think I can do it, do you?
I didn't say that.
The truth is, I'd be fascinated to see what you have in mind.
In that case, why don't you stay and observe?
If you insist.
What's wrong?
I don't know... it's like a cramp or something.
You shouldn't be feeling any pain.
Well... it appears that you're not going to be having the baby today.
What?
You were in labor too long.
I wonder why...
For whatever reason... you weren't able to fully relax. Your system had to stop producing endorphins before they accumulated to toxic levels.
When will she have the baby?
It could be a few more days, or a few more weeks.
Weeks? If I don't have this baby soon, I'm going to lose my mind.
If you want, you can go see Doctor Bashir and have him --
No. I want to have this baby the traditional Bajoran way.
We're a hundred percent behind you. Aren't we, Miles? O'Brien's thinking about the idea of going to Julian, until Keiko nudges him.
Absolutely.
Can you stay for a while?
I'll have to rearrange my schedule, but I think so.
Nerys, return to your quarters and rest. I'll come by and see you later.
You... be punctual next time or don't come at all.
And you... practice.
This is a sphere. It's one of the most basic forms in nature. See how it rolls? Interesting, isn't it?
You're blocking my light.
Now... this won't hurt a bit...
This is also a sphere. Feel its symmetry... the softness of its shape... the sameness.
Now you try it...
Here's a little reminder.

I realize you prefer to remain shapeless... believe me, I remember how relaxing it could be. But you have to learn to take other forms. It's what changelings do. It's immensely rewarding. I remember the first time Doctor Mora here coerced me into taking the shape of a cube with one of his electrostatic gadgets. Once I did it, and he turned the infernal thing off, I was perfectly content to stay a cube for hours. It was fascinating -- all those right angles. of course, he had other plans. The next thing I knew, he had me spinning around in a centrifuge.
If you're not interested in a sphere right now, we can always try a cube.
Now... all you have to do is hold this shape. Ready?
All right... you're starting to catch on...
What are you doing?
I'm just measuring its volume.
It's been almost a week and it's only grown seventeen percent. After three days in my lab, you were twice this size.
Maybe I was anxious to grow up so I could get out of there.
My point is that you've made no progress. By this time, I'd already gotten you to mimic half a dozen simple forms.
I'm trying to gain its trust, not teach it tricks.
It's a shame you're not a changeling anymore -- you could just link with it and teach it everything it needs to know.
You make it sound like it's my fault.
It might very well be.
Let's face it, Odo, your shape-shifting abilities were somewhat limited. That may be why your people were able to force you to take humanoid form.
That's pure speculation.
Why don't we run some tests and find out?
You're just dying to get me into one of your contraptions, aren't you?
I'm trying to help.
I'm not about to submit myself to another round of your experiments.
Everything I did to you was for your own good. True, some of the tests I subjected you to proved inconclusive --
The vacuum chamber springs to mind, the cytoplasmic separator... and come to think of it, the protein decompiler, too --
How could I know until I tried? By the Prophets, Odo, I wasn't even sure you were a lifeform.

Once I realized you were sentient, the Cardassians wanted to know everything about you. I was under enormous pressure to get results. And I did. My techniques worked. The fact that you're standing here whining about them is proof.
You enjoyed watching me suffer.
Do you really believe that? How pathetic. If it weren't for me, you'd still be sitting on a shelf somewhere, in a beaker labeled "unknown sample."
If it weren't for me, you'd be a nobody -- Starfleet wouldn't hire you to judge a science fair.

I'm getting a little tired of standing around watching you. But I can't seem to pull myself away. I'm too curious to see what preposterous thing you'll try next. Who knows, maybe after a few months, it'll get so tired of your incessant chatter it'll actually do something.
You'd love to get your hands on it, wouldn't you? You could sell tickets on the Promenade. Doctor Mora's Chamber of Horrors -- open for business.
Come on in...
Captain...
How's it going, gentlemen?
Making progress.
Glad to hear it. I was just talking with Starfleet Command.
They want you to establish communication with the changeling as soon as possible.
At the rate we're going, that's still a long way off.
Better not be too long, otherwise Starfleet is going to want to take over the project.
Sir?
As long as you're making progress, there's nothing to worry about.
By the way, Starfleet would like you to file daily reports for their review.
Understood, sir.
Carry on.
Well... now you have an idea of the kind of pressure I was under.
I brought my old equipment up from Bajor. Maybe it's time we started unpacking it.
Whenever you're ready.
Don't worry, you'll get through this...
No, no -- I'm just an observer.
Odo, it won't respond to anything less than six millivolts.
There must be some other way.

Spare the rod, spoil the child. Without discomfort, the changeling is perfectly content to stay in its gelatinous state. It'll just lie there, never realizing it has the ability to mimic other forms, never living up to its potential. Six millivolts isn't going to harm it. Once it realizes there's no charge inside the circle, the procedure will be over.
Checking to see if I'm enjoying myself... ?
That's it... you've found it...
I smiled the first time you did that... little did I know you'd end up hating me for it. Shall we move on?
Why not.
Edon...
How're you feeling?
I'm all right. My feet are a little swollen.
A little? They've never been this bad.
There's a zero-grav tumbling performance on the Promenade tonight -- want to go?
Well, maybe.
You can't be standing around for an hour.
Chief, would you mind leaving us alone for a minute?
I'm almost done.
I'll take over.
I think it's time.
You have to do it harder.
I know what I'm doing.
It's time.
You have to work your way up the leg. KIRA It's time!
If I were you I'd hold this shape... otherwise you'll be in for a little shock...
This is a smart one... I had to do that three times before you caught on.
Actually... The first two times I didn't hold the shape on purpose.
You're not serious.
I suppose I didn't want to give you the satisfaction.
Well... if you're lucky, someday this changeling will give you the satisfaction of saying, "Thank you, you did so much for me." Then again, maybe it'll just end up leaving the way you did.
Without any warning, it'll just announce that it's striking out on its own -- and you'll never hear from it again.
I'm going to get something to eat...
And the eyes! Incredible.
For a minute there, I thought it was going to say something.
Put that down, we're celebrating.
It's just that I've fallen behind on my security reports these last few days.
You can catch up later. Aren't you excited about what happened?
Of course I am.
Tomorrow, we can start exposing the changeling to simple life- forms so that it can mimic them. Algae, fungus -- in a few days, maybe even an invertebrate.
I can't wait until I can actually talk to it. There's so much I want it to see, so much I want to share.
You'll get the chance sooner than you think. The changeling is developing far faster than you did.
I didn't mean that as a criticism. If anything, it's a compliment.

I was wrong. Your approach to communicating with the changeling was sound. Don't you see? It was reaching out to you. It was curious about you. The first time you did anything even close to that was when you formed a tentacle to slap my hand away from the control panel.
I remember. I wanted you to stop zapping me.
You've formed a connection with that changeling. That's something I never managed to do with you.
That's not true. I respected you.
You feared me.
You didn't know what I was. You were experimenting on what looked like a lump of organic residue. And that's what I'd still be if it weren't for you.
You don't know how much it means to me to hear you say that.
I'm sorry. I know that sort of talk makes you uncomfortable.
I suppose it's my fault, in a way. If I hadn't poked and prodded at you so much, you might have ended up with a less... forbidding disposition.
Something tells me that no matter what we do to that changeling, it's going to have a more pleasant disposition than mine. It's just the way I am.
Doctor Mora.
Two glasses of champagne, please. We're celebrating...
The baby's turned... it's time.
Awake child...
We await you with love...
And welcome you into the world....
Why don't you stay there?
I can't see from here.
Exactly.
Look, it's my baby.
Shh.
I think it would make Nerys uncomfortable.
She's been living in my home for the last five months.
Ouiet.
What's that supposed to mean?
I missed Molly's birth, I'm not about to miss this one.
I'm trying to have a baby here.
I'm sick of this ridiculous little competition you two have going. If either one of you says another word, you're going to have to leave.
Fine, tell him to Just tell him to let me -- to stay where--
That's it. Get out. Both of you.
Nerys -- Kira --
Go.
You're joking.
Does it sound like she's joking?
Nice going.
Do me a favor -- next time you have a baby, leave my girlfriend out of it.
-- comes to... Three hundred and twenty-four... I'm going to have to start watering the drinks again...
Constable?
Quark!
What are you doing back there?
What does it look like?
We're closed.
Have a seat.
You're in a good mood.
Yes, I am.
Which means you're probably about to arrest me on some trumped up charge.
Not at all. I'm buying you a drink.
Why?
Because Doctor Mora went to bed, and I still feel like celebrating.
What are you up to?
I'm happy, Quark. Can't you just accept that?
No. It doesn't fit. If you're happy, something's very wrong in the world... ... the center cannot not hold.
There we go.
I've got it -- you're getting back at me for selling you that sick changeling.
Actually, I should thank you.
If you want the money back, just say so.
It changed my life... To you, Quark.
All right, all right -- I confess. I don't know what I did, but I did it. Just stop, I can't take it anymore.
Do you ever think about having children?
Huh?
I never did. It seemed like too much trouble. But fate dropped one into my lap. And now... I couldn't be happier. Cheers...

It's strange... over the past few months, I came to accept the fact that I'd never have any contact with my people again. They'd rejected me, turned me into a humanoid. And a part of me was lost forever. But that little ball of goo sitting in that lab changed everything. I feel like I'm experiencing what it is to be a changeling again. And somehow, being a solid doesn't seem so bad anymore.
Fill me up.
Security Chief Odo, please acknowledge.
Go ahead.
The lifeform being monitored is displaying biomimetic fluctuations beyond stated parameters...
Have Doctor Mora meet me in the Science Lab.
Acknowledged.
What's happened?
It's morphogenic matrix is destablizing...
It's dying...
Its lifesigns are fading. The radiation may have damaged its cytoplasm in some way we weren't able to detect.
There must be something you can do.
We could try an enzymatic induction -- that might stabilize the biomimetic fluctuations.
It's worth a shot.
It has to work, it has to.
Odo, please... Why don't you wait outside. We'll do what we can.
I feel... so good...
You're doing great, Nerys.
Here he comes...
Keiko... would you do me a favor?
Kira says you can both come back in if you promise to behave.
After you.
No -- after you.
Please.
Will you two get in here... you're going to miss everything.
That's it, Nerys... relax -- let it come...
Look at him, Miles...
He's beautiful...
Well... ?
There's nothing we can do. I'm sorry. It won't be long now...
Please, don't die... there's so much I want to show you. I was going to teach you how to become a Tarkalean Hawk... remember?
What happened, where did it go?
It somehow integrated itself into Odo's body...
Odo --
What's wrong?
It can't be...
What... ?
This might be a good time to take some leave and come down to Bajor for a while.
Maybe in a few weeks. Right now, I feel like staying around here.
So you can be close to the baby...
He's a good-looking boy.
He is, isn't he?
All passengers bound for Bajor should board at this time.
You'd better go.
I've got a few minutes left.
So... how does it feel to be yourself again?
I just wish it hadn't happened the way it did...
I'm sorry. If it helps, think of it as a gift -- something the changeling wanted you to have.
I think I finally understand how much I meant to you... and what you must've gone through when I left.
You had to find your own way in the world.
I should've included you in my life.
You still can.
Take care of yourself, Odo...
I thought the O'Briens were having a party.
Oh?
I got into this because the O'Briens' needed my help -- I never wanted a baby. But right now... I just wish I could hold him in my arms and never let go.
Want to take a walk?
... the Defiant searched the area for almost six hours, but we couldn't find any sign of survivors.
The Cortez was a fine ship.
You knew Captain Swofford a long time.
I introduced him to his wife.
Patrolling the Cardassian border is getting more and more dangerous. You never know when you're going to run into a squadron of Jem'Hadar fighters.
I guess we popped the champagne corks too soon.
Everyone thought the war was over when we retook the station and pushed the Dominion back into Cardassian space.
I never believed that... and neither did you.
A lot of good that did the four hundred people on the Cortez.
Mister Sisko. So, how do you like our station so far?
It certainly is big.
I heard about Quentin Swofford. I'm sorry.
Look, Dad... I know I haven't been very good company the last few days.
I didn't come here to be entertained. I came to see you and Jake.
You picked an interesting time to take your first trip away from Earth.
Well, I figured it was now or never. Besides, I've been worried about you. Last couple of times we've talked... it seemed like the weight of the entire Alpha Quadrant was on your shoulders.
Sometimes it feels that way.
Dad... I'm not sure...
Just say it, son.
I just don't know how many friends I can lose. Every time I think I've achieved a real victory... something like this happens and it all turns to ashes.
So what do you want to do?
Maybe it's time for me to step down... let someone else make the tough calls.
I see. Well, no one's indispensable, son. Not even you. Whatever decision you make, I'll support it. Of course, if Quentin Swofford was here... I'd bet he'd have a few things to say to you.
But he's not here... is he? That's the whole point.
I'd say you have some thinking to do... and I've got a dinner date with my grandson, so I'll let you get to it.
Who was that?
Where'd he go?
Who?
The man who just walked by my door.
I didn't see anyone.
I could've sworn...
I don't know what you're so worried about, Ben. I'm not taking my ship anywhere near the Cardassian border.
I realize that. But the Dominion is getting bolder and bolder... and your freighter is no match for a Jem'Hadar attack ship.
They'd have to catch me first.
You're really not worried, are you?
Me? I'm fearless. You know that -- that's why you love me.
I think I follow that logic.
Hey, Benny. See the game last night?
What?
Ben?
Who was that?
Who was who?
Ben -- where are you going?
Ben -- what's wrong? Are you hurt?
He's awake. Ben, are you all right?
I think so...
Thank God.
Hey, Dad. You scared us there for a minute.
What happened?
I'm not sure. I'm reading some unusual synaptic potentials. The neural patterns are similar to those you experienced last year.
You mean when I was having those... visions about Bajor?
Visions? Does this have something to do with those Prophets you're always telling me about?
Could be.
He's not going to need surgery again, is he?
I don't know yet. But I'd like you to remain overnight for observation.
Are you sure that's necessary?
Absolutely. Take a look at these readings --
You gonna buy that or not?
Personally, I don't see the attraction. Spaceships, flying saucers, men from Mars...
What's wrong with men from Mars?
Nothing, except it's all make- believe. Me -- I like war stories. Did you see From Here to Eternity? Burt Lancaster standing there, in the middle of Pearl Harbor... machine gun blazing...
(making the sound of gunfire) ... shooting down those zeros. If it had been flying saucers... forget about it. So you gonna buy that or not?
Benny.
Hello, Albert.
I thought... that is if you're on the way to the office...
... we could walk there together?
Exactly.
Ah, there they are.
Voila. A pitcher of plain water instantly becomes a pitcher of ice tea.
Incredible.
White Rose Redi-Tea. What an appalling concept.
I bet H. G. Wells would've liked it.
I doubt that. No self-respecting Englishman would.
Pabst!
Pabst! Get out here.
What's wrong now, Herb?
I'll give you one guess.
The battle of the doughnuts, round twenty-eight.
That's what you called me out here for -- to complain about the doughnuts?
They're stale again.
Delicious.
Delicious my eye -- these are two days old and you know it.
I've been eating doughnuts my whole life and these weren't baked more than -- -- six hours ago.
That's it, I quit. I'm going over to Galaxy.
That rag?
I bet that rag knows the difference between a doughnut and a doorstop.
You want to write Galaxy, go ahead. But Who's winning? they're not going to pay you four cents a word for KAY your stories. A draw... same as always.
(looking for his You're paying him four matches again) cents a word? Did you see where I put...
You're paying him four matches again) cents a word? Did you see where I put...
Stay out of this, Julius. ... the matches? I gave them to you.
If he's getting four, Kay and I should at least get Then they should be three. here...
For that fantasy crap you (re: Benny's write? You're lucky to magazine) be getting two. What's that?
The latest Galaxy. I beg your pardon.
Hey. Benny has the new issue of "Galaxy".
Heinlein, Bradbury, Sturgeon... quite a lineup. Add Herbert Rossoff and it's complete.
What if I promise you fresh doughnuts tomorrow?
Why should I believe you?
I'll even throw in a couple of crullers.
Okay, I'll stay.
Don't do us any favors.
All right, now that we've taken care of the old business...
... onto the new. Time to hand out next month's story assignments. Ritterhouse! We're waiting.
Coming.
All right, friends and neighbors, let's see what Uncle Roy brought you today...
I've titled this one... "Please, Take Me With You." Who wants this one?
(getting a nod from his wife) I think we can do something with that.
I bet you can. I can see it now -- the lonely little girl, befriended by empathetic aliens who teach her how to smile. It's enough to make you go out and buy a television. Next.
You've got to be kidding...
What can I say? I had extra sauerkraut on my franks that night.
Be that as it may, it's still the worst piece of garbage I've ever seen. I'll take it.
Of course you will. You've an affinity for garbage, don't you?
The picture may be garbage, but the story... the story will be art.
I don't have a title for it yet...
I'll think of something.
Next order of business, some of our readers have been writing in wanting to know what you people look like.
Write back and tell them we look like writers. Poor, needy and incredibly attractive.
The publisher has come up with a better idea. Mister Stone has decided to run a picture of you in next month's issue.
Is this really...
... necessary? I'm afraid so.
Kay... you can sleep late that day.
Of course I can. God forbid that the public ever finds out K.C. Hunter is a woman.
I suppose I'm sleeping late that day, too.
It's not personal, Benny. But as far as our readers are concerned, Benny Russell is as white as they are. Let's just leave it that way.
If the world's not ready for a woman writer -- imagine what would happen if it learned about a Negro with a typewriter -- run for the hills! It's the end of civilization!
What about James Baldwin, Richard Wright, Zora Neal Hurston, Langston Hughes? Ever heard of Native Son?
That's literature for liberals and intellectuals. The average reader isn't going to spend his hard-earned cash on stories written by Negroes.
Would someone please shoot me and put me out of my misery?
How I long for a gun.
I'm sorry, Benny. I wish things were different, but they're not.
Wishing never changed a damn thing.
Come on, Benny... it's just a photo.
I'll try to remember that.
You're a dog.
All right, enough standing around. Get back to work.
What's all the hurry?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: That's my drawing.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Is that so?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Nice suit. Where'd you get it?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: I bought it. Can I have my drawing back?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Hey boy, I'd watch that tone of voice if I were you.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: What are you doing around here?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: I work here.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Where?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: In there.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: What are you -- the janitor?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Awfully well-dressed for a janitor.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: How do we know the picture's yours?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: (struggling to maintain his composure) It's a drawing of a space station.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Space station?
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Well, get off it.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: See -- it's not worth anything, except to me.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT

quote: Let's run him in, check him for priors.
scene: 22   EXT. NEW YORK STREET - OFFICE BUILDING - NIGHT
